repnme.cdata!: India - Third Power System Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Third Power System
            Development (PSDP III) Project for India were as follows:
            outcomes were highly satisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was low or negligible, the Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: impact of
            compliance with the negative pledge clause: This process
            required a careful and lengthy preparation of the security
            package by Power Grid Corporation of India Limited
            (POWERGRID) which delayed loan effectiveness by about six
            months (July 31 to December 15, 2006). It would have been
            useful to resolve this aspect earlier during preparation so
            that implementation could proceed according to the planned
            timeline. This is a broader lesson for the India portfolio.
            However, the resolution of this issue and experience gained
            during the approval process resulted in the streamlining of
            the approval of PSDP IV and V by the World Bank. Using
            operational and project management experience, POWERGRID has
            effectively contributed to the success of the project.
            Moreover, this project has shown that continuous reviews and
            improvements of POWERGRID's technical implementation,
            procurement and safeguards systems have elevated the
            standards to be followed by others. Procurement is a
            delicate matter and with its overlapping synergies with the
            technical aspects, it is always a tough and contentious
            issue. Thus, even though there was a regular communication
            (both formal and informal) between POWERGRID and the Bank
            during the entire project period, an additional exchange
            forum, which could be in the form of regular face-to-face
            meetings, between the Bank and POWERGRID to discuss such
            complex matters in even more detail shall help in future engagements.

repnme.cdata!:
India - Third Power System Development
            Project : environmental and social assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental and social assessment
            for the Third Power System Development Project for India
            outlines possible negative impacts and proposes measures to
            mitigate them. Expected negative environmental impacts can
            be mitigated as follows: Avoid affecting natural and
            socio-cultural resources by carefully selecting routes using
            techniques/tools like GIS and GPS aerial photography. Obtain
            prior approval and have forestry department supervise when
            passing transmission lines through forest and protected
            areas. Provide construction crews with fuel wood or
            alternative fuels to minimize fuel collecting. Pay
            compensation for crop damage or other damage to farmland,
            and restore on-farm works after construction ends. Reroute
            telecom circuits, convert overhead telecom circuits into
            cables, etc. to minimize voltage interference. Maintain
            adequate clearance between transmission lines and railways,
            civil aviation, and defense installations. Paint airport
            towers beyond specified height for easy visibility and place
            warning lights on top of these towers. Where drainage is
            affected, train flow and guide it to safe zones. Adopt
            safety measures to avoid fires due to flashover from lines.
            Resurface the areas where excavation works are done. Restore
            surfaces with topsoil. Select dumping areas to for rocky
            material and use as fill for tower foundations. Plant trees
            along roads to buffer visual effect. Paint towers to blend
            into background. Provide sound and vibration dampers, and
            maintain equipment to reduce noise. Reduce nuisance to
            nearby properties by using tractors and manual labor.
            Execute work during light traffic periods. Avoid rainy
            season, cut and fill slopes, use retaining walls, and sow
            soil-binding grasses to control erosion. Protect worker
            health and safety. There are no significant issues regarding
            management of levels of polychlorinated biphenyls PCBs)
            formerly used as insulating material in capacitors and transformers.

repnme.cdata!:
India - Third Power System Development
            Project : social assessment and resettlement action plan

abstracts.cdata!:
This resettlement action plan presents
            demographics about project-affected persons (PAPs) in
            Punjab, Haryana, Rajasthan, and Delhi, the main beneficiary
            states; provides a focus on the most vulnerable segments;
            outlines the criteria determining entitlement and providing
            for compensation and rehabilitation assistance; describes
            how the public was consulted about the process and affords
            the affected population a mechanism to redress grievances;
            and discusses how the resettlement policy will be carried
            out and monitored. Compensation will be paid for land
            acquisition (land for land will be offered as an option and
            loss of structures (houses, shops, cattle sheds. After a
            socioeconomic survey is done, income generation schemes will
            be set up to offset loss of livelihood or occupation. Job
            opportunities will come from the project itself as well as
            from horticulture, sweeping, maintenance contracts, etc.
            PAPs having experience in construction work will receive
            some contract work on a preferential basis. Communities
            losing access to common property resources and facilities
            will have them replaced. The loss of urban civic amenities
            lost will entitle communities to equivalent amenities or
            services. Beneficiary families will be entitled to cash
            compensation at market rates for lost crops and to fixed
            compensation for loss of fruit-bearing trees. Beneficiary
            families will be provided transport or equivalent cash for
            relocation of material/cattle. The beneficiary host
            community will be entitled to augmented resources to sustain
            pressure of PAPs moving to their area.

repnme.cdata!: India - Third Power System Development Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Third Power System Development
            Project for India aims to strengthen the transmission system
            in order to increase reliable power exchanges between the
            regions and states of India. The Project would support
            POWERGRID's investment program of system strengthening
            in the various regions and developing inter-regional
            transmission links to enhance the power exchange capacities,
            eventually helping enhance the national power grid. There
            are two project components. Component A, transmission system
            strengthening schemes, includes strengthening of the intra
            and inter-regional transmission systems for greater energy
            security, system reliability and to enhance inter-regional
            power exchanges. Technical assistance will be considered for
            enhancing inter-regional power exchange capacities and
            building a data base of the system. Component B, completion
            of balance works of the PSDP-I1 project, finances the
            completion of some of the investment schemes financed under
            the Second Power System Development Project (loan 4603-IN,
            report no. 21609) after its closing date.
